trans-unit.source: Transactions in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Transactions in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Tips for implementing transactions in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.
trans-unit.target: Tips for implementing transactions in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.

trans-unit.source: As you would expect SQL Data Warehouse does offer support for all transactional properties.
trans-unit.target: As you would expect SQL Data Warehouse does offer support for all transactional properties.

trans-unit.source: However, to ensure the performance of SQL Data Warehouse is maintained at scale some features are limited when compared to SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: However, to ensure the performance of SQL Data Warehouse is maintained at scale some features are limited when compared to SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: This article hightlights the differences and lists the others.
trans-unit.target: This article hightlights the differences and lists the others.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse implements ACID transactions.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse implements ACID transactions.

trans-unit.source: However, the Isolation of the transactional support is limited to READ UNCOMMITTED and this cannot be changed.
trans-unit.target: However, the Isolation of the transactional support is limited to READ UNCOMMITTED and this cannot be changed.

trans-unit.source: You can implement a number of coding methods to prevent dirty reads of data if this is a concern for you.
trans-unit.target: You can implement a number of coding methods to prevent dirty reads of data if this is a concern for you.

trans-unit.source: The most popular methods leverage both CTAS and table partition switching (often known as the sliding window pattern) to prevent users from querying data that is still being prepared.
trans-unit.target: The most popular methods leverage both CTAS and table partition switching (often known as the sliding window pattern) to prevent users from querying data that is still being prepared.

trans-unit.source: Views that pre-filter the data is also a popular approach.
trans-unit.target: Views that pre-filter the data is also a popular approach.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse uses the XACT_STATE() function to report a failed transaction using the value -2.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse uses the XACT_STATE() function to report a failed transaction using the value -2.

trans-unit.source: This means that the transaction has failed and is marked for rollback only
trans-unit.target: This means that the transaction has failed and is marked for rollback only

trans-unit.source: The use of -2 by the XACT_STATE function to denote a failed transaction represents different behavior to SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: The use of -2 by the XACT_STATE function to denote a failed transaction represents different behavior to SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server uses the value -1 to represent an un-committable transaction.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server uses the value -1 to represent an un-committable transaction.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server can tolerate some errors inside a transaction without it having to be marked as un-committable.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server can tolerate some errors inside a transaction without it having to be marked as un-committable.

trans-unit.source: For example SELECT 1/0 would cause an error but not force a transaction into an un-committable state.
trans-unit.target: For example SELECT 1/0 would cause an error but not force a transaction into an un-committable state.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server also permits reads in the un-committable transaction.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server also permits reads in the un-committable transaction.

trans-unit.source: However, in SQLDW this is not the case.
trans-unit.target: However, in SQLDW this is not the case.

trans-unit.source: If an error occurs inside a SQLDW transaction it will automatically enter the -2 state: including SELECT 1/0 errors.
trans-unit.target: If an error occurs inside a SQLDW transaction it will automatically enter the -2 state: including SELECT 1/0 errors.

trans-unit.source: It is therefore important to check that your application code to see if it uses XACT_STATE().
trans-unit.target: It is therefore important to check that your application code to see if it uses XACT_STATE().

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server you might see a code fragment that looks like this:
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server you might see a code fragment that looks like this:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the SELECT statement occurs before the ROLLBACK statement.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the SELECT statement occurs before the ROLLBACK statement.

trans-unit.source: Also note that the setting of the @xact variable uses DECLARE and not SELECT.
trans-unit.target: Also note that the setting of the @xact variable uses DECLARE and not SELECT.

trans-unit.source: In SQL Data Warehouse the code would need to look like this:
trans-unit.target: In SQL Data Warehouse the code would need to look like this:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the rollback of the transaction has to happen before the read of the error information in the CATCH Block.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the rollback of the transaction has to happen before the read of the error information in the CATCH Block.

trans-unit.source: It is also worth noting that SQL Data Warehouse does not implement or support the ERROR_LINE() function.
trans-unit.target: It is also worth noting that SQL Data Warehouse does not implement or support the ERROR_LINE() function.

trans-unit.source: If you have this in your code you will need to remove it to be compliant with SQL Data Warehouse.
trans-unit.target: If you have this in your code you will need to remove it to be compliant with SQL Data Warehouse.

trans-unit.source: Use query labels in your code instead to implement equivalent functionality.
trans-unit.target: Use query labels in your code instead to implement equivalent functionality.

trans-unit.source: Please refer to the [query labels] article for more details on this feature.
trans-unit.target: Please refer to the [query labels] article for more details on this feature.

trans-unit.source: THROW is the more modern implementation for raising exceptions in SQL Data Warehouse but RAISERROR is also supported.
trans-unit.target: THROW is the more modern implementation for raising exceptions in SQL Data Warehouse but RAISERROR is also supported.

trans-unit.source: There are a few differences that are worth paying attention to however.
trans-unit.target: There are a few differences that are worth paying attention to however.

trans-unit.source: User defined error messages numbers cannot be in the 100,000 - 150,000 range for THROW
trans-unit.target: User defined error messages numbers cannot be in the 100,000 - 150,000 range for THROW

trans-unit.source: RAISERROR error messages are fixed at 50,000
trans-unit.target: RAISERROR error messages are fixed at 50,000

trans-unit.source: Use of sys.messages is not supported
trans-unit.target: Use of sys.messages is not supported

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse does have a few other restrictions that relate to transactions.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse does have a few other restrictions that relate to transactions.

trans-unit.source: They are as follows:
trans-unit.target: They are as follows:

trans-unit.source: No distributed transactions
trans-unit.target: No distributed transactions

trans-unit.source: No nested transactions permitted
trans-unit.target: No nested transactions permitted

trans-unit.source: No save points allowed
trans-unit.target: No save points allowed

trans-unit.source: For more development tips, see <linkText>development overview</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more development tips, see <linkText>development overview</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: sql-data-warehouse-overview-develop.md
trans-unit.target: sql-data-warehouse-overview-develop.md
